description: From Middle English treden, from Old English tredan, from Proto-West Germanic *tredan, from Proto-Germanic *trudaną.

verbs.description: tread (third-person singular simple present treads, present participle treading, simple past trod or tread or treaded, past participle trodden or trod or tread or treaded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To step or walk (on or across something); to trample.
examples: He trod back and forth wearily.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To step or walk upon.
(figuratively, with certain adverbs of manner) To proceed, to behave (in a certain manner).
examples: to tread lightly, to tread gently
to tread carefully, to tread cautiously, to tread warily

entries.meaning: To beat or press with the feet.
examples: to tread a path; to tread land when too light; a well-trodden path

entries.meaning: To work a lever, treadle, etc., with the foot or the feet.
To go through or accomplish by walking, dancing, etc.
To crush under the foot; to trample in contempt or hatred; to subdue.
(intransitive) To copulate; said of (especially male) birds.
(transitive, of a male bird) To copulate with.
(transitive) To crush grapes with one's feet to make wine

description: From Middle English tred, from treden (“to tread”).

entries.meaning: A step taken with the foot.
A manner of stepping.
examples: She is coming, my own, my sweet; / Were it ever so airy a tread, / My heart would hear her and beat.

entries.meaning: The sound made when someone or something is walking.
examples: The steps fell lightly and oddly, with a certain swing, for all they went so slowly; it was different indeed from the heavy creaking tread of Henry Jekyll. Utterson sighed. "Is there never anything else?" he asked.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A way; a track or path.
The horizontal part of a step in a flight of stairs.
The grooves carved into the face of a tire, used to give the tire traction. [from 1900s]
The grooves on the bottom of a shoe or other footwear, used to give grip or traction.
(biology) The chalaza of a bird's egg; the treadle.
The act of avian copulation in which the male bird mounts the female by standing on her back.
(fortification) The top of the banquette, on which soldiers stand to fire over the parapet.
A bruise or abrasion produced on the foot or ankle of a horse that interferes, or strikes its feet together.
